['Wicketkeeper: A fielder stationed behind the stumps, ready to catch balls delivered by the bowler and keep wickets if they are hit off the ground.', "Backward point: An outfielder situated in a defensive position near the popping crease during the fielding of deliveries aimed at the batsman's body or front leg.", 'Slip cordon: A pair of fielders, usually two people, placed behind the batsmen and close to their bodies for quick catch opportunities.', "Leg slip: An individual fielder positioned on the off side just outside the popping crease, covering deliveries aimed at a batsman's front leg.", 'Gatting (or gully): A fielding position named after English cricketer Ian Botham, where the fielder is placed in a semi-open area near the bowler and stumps.', "Fine leg: An outfielder located on the off side close to the boundary line during the fielding of deliveries targeted at batsmen's bodies or front legs.", 'Third man (or cover): A fielder positioned behind square-leg, covering the area directly adjacent to the batsman for catches and stumpings.', 'Deep point: An outfielder situated in a long-range fielding location on the off side near the boundary during bowling deliveries aimed at hitting boundaries or wide balls.', 'Midwicket: A pair of fielders positioned between square leg and cover, covering areas for catches and stumpings.', "Short leg (or short fine): An outfielder placed close to the batsman's feet near the popping crease during bowling deliveries aimed at hitting boundaries or wide balls.", 'Sweeper: A fielder positioned deep in the field, primarily for catching edges and preventing run-outs.', 'Long leg (or long fine): An outfielder located on the off side nearer to the boundary than third man during bowling deliveries aimed at hitting boundaries or wide balls.', 'Sweep: A fielding strategy where a fielder stands close to the batsman, attempting to catch edges that might come from aggressive shots like sweeping or swaying.', 'Bowler cover: An outfielder positioned behind square leg and nearer to the stumps, mainly for stumping opportunities during bowling deliveries aimed at hitting boundaries.', 'On-drive field: A fielder located on the off side directly in front of a batsman when the ball is hit straight down the ground.', 'Backward point catcher: The player responsible for standing behind the stumps and catching any balls that pass between them and the wicket during bowling deliveries aimed at hitting boundaries or wide balls.', 'Throwdown (or leg before wicket): An outfielder placed in a semi-open position just outside square on the off side, waiting to prevent batsmen from hitting the ball towards their wickets with an attempt for LBW dismissal.', 'Long-hop catch: A fielder standing deep in the field aiming to take catches when a bowled delivery goes high and short over the batsman\'s head (a "long hop").', 'Bowler slip: The player positioned on the off side, slightly closer to the stumps than the regular slips, mainly for attempting catches during bowling deliveries aimed at hitting boundaries or wide balls.', 'Cutter fielding position: An outfielder situated deep in the crease (just behind and nearer to the batsman), anticipating catches when a spinner delivers a deceptive "cut" ball that moves away from the off side.']
